segments.text: We're about to begin an interview with Reverend William B. Rogers of Denton, Texas.
It's April 6, 1984, and we'll be discussing the Civil Rights Movement during the 1950s and early 60s, especially concerning Prince Edward County, where Reverend Rogers lived for several years.
To begin, could you give a general background of your upbringing, where you were born, and just kind of a general view of leading into how you ended up in Prince Edward County?
Well, this is very pertinent to the subject because there is a good bit of background here that leads up to a quite accidental presence in Prince Edward County at that particular time.
But my background was very much in the civil rights movements of the old south long ago because my dad was one of the old school southern liberals lawyers in Arkansas.
And he got into some real difficulties with the body politic and other things.
He was a young assistant attorney general of the state at a time when a preliminary kind of Scottsboro case, if you're familiar with that, in Alabama, happened in Arkansas.
And he was able to defuse this a good bit in his investigations and reports and so forth, and the refusal of the state to prosecute
some blacks who were accused of rape.
But as it turned out, money had changed hands.
It was strictly an act of prostitution on the part of the white woman with the black men.
But this was quite a lesson for my dad.
This was back in the early 20s.
He discovered in this case that he would never be able to stand for public office in Arkansas, which was his goal.
because he had some real political ambitions.
As it turned out, the Attorney General, who was the elected officer he was working with, was defeated the next time on the basis of his support of my dad.
So there's a long history here, and a lot of the things in the political realm
that my dad worked for.
He was an ardent new dealer, for instance, when the time came.
In fact, he was on Roosevelt's first list of federal judge appointees.
He turned it down at the time because he said he couldn't feed his family on what the federal judge was paid in those days.
But he, later on, in Little Rock and in El Dorado,
he got the reputation of what was, he was called a nigger lawyer.
And a nigger lawyer was somebody who would stand up for the blacks in the courts and often defend them and some of their difficulties and so forth.
So this, there's a long tradition here in the South and in the Deep South as far as these things are concerned and I suppose I became pretty much an heir to my own heritage in
and how this developed.
In my first pastorate in Brooklyn, Brooklyn, New York, the church integrated for the first time in subsequent years with a pastor who moved in to stay following me.
It's about a 50-50 black and white church.
The block had been busted while I was there, and we were able to reduce some of the barriers
And, of course, when a block is busted in the city, this is a traumatic experience for the old blind whites who lived there and so forth.
But this was in the central part of Brooklyn, and, of course, the blacks had pretty well taken over, or were taking over at that time.
A real model, I think.
I can't take any of the credit for it, because it's been the work of a white pastor in that situation who actively sought the blacks within the church.
But at least I had a role in it starting, and I take some pride in that.
But my next pastorate was in Prince Edward County.
I was chaplain of Hampton-Sydney College and pastor of the college church, which was about half the college community, which was right out in the country.
Of course, this was the seat back in 1776 when the college was founded.
But the town moved seven miles away to Farmville, which is the county seat of Prince Edward County.
And Hampton-Sydney College, the church was right in the middle of the college campus.
Of course, it's a Presbyterian church-related college.
And it was quite a challenge for a lot of ways.
Now, Prince Edward County is about as deep south as you can find, even in places like Mississippi.
It's Southside, Virginia.
It has its traditions, its peculiar Virginia-type traditions.
People like Patrick Henry and James Madison were natives of the county.
It has quite a tradition.
It's right next to Appomattox where the final surrender took place.
The final battles actually took place in Prince Edward County where Lee's forces were retreating toward Appomattox.
finally caught up with at that point.
But there was an issue there from the very beginning.
The quality of the schools, separate but equal so-called schools, in Prince Edward County were very poor.
And the educational level of the blacks in that county was pretty low.
In fact, some of the
Some of the very dear white people who protested and were in the way of the integration of the schools simply had never known blacks who had more than a high school education.
Now, of course, a high school education in Prince Edward County wasn't worth very much to the people who were graduating from Hartford.
Of course, this had been a continuing problem with all black schools all the way through.
So when the NAACP, Thurgood Marshall was the key person in all of this.
He was the one who was working through the courts as a means for providing educational opportunity for black children.
And incidentally, I'm a great admirer of Thurgood Marshall.
I got to know him at that point.
greatly admire some of the things he did.
I haven't seen him more than on a couple of occasions.
But he was the legal brain who pushed this thing through and saw this one legal point as a point of breakthrough for educational opportunity.
There was another black lawyer named Hill from Richmond who was also involved in the NAACP.
There's no question, but as the Whites and Prince Edward pointed out, that this was all agitated by outside agitators.
But the caliber of those agitators was something else again.
It was the NAACP.
They saw in Prince Edward County and simultaneous with this, the other county, three other counties, I believe, Delaware and Kansas, South Carolina.

they saw an opportunity for several cases to come before the Supreme Court at the same time and have a definitive decision on this subject to do away with the separate but equal, which was of course really unequal.
So, there were meetings, some of the
More educated blacks in the county were involved, and there were a very few of us whites, only two or three who were involved.
I was in the only real educational center.
There was another college in Farmerville, a woman's college, but Hampton-Sydney was very much a traditional Virginia-type institution.
almost a small Ivy League-type school.
The students there were largely rural Virginia, conservative in background, but yet of the first families in this kind of land.
And all the way through, the issues that remained, I was never able to rally much support from the students there.

This was before the days of student activism, and I despaired of students ever being useful or involved in anything that might mean some progress as far as educational opportunities and others were concerned.
But this ran through the course in the county here.
It wasn't an issue to a lot of people.
It was just an issue to those of us who were interested in it until it came as one of the suits before the Supreme Court.
One of the incidents I remember particularly in this, I had taken a stand from the pulpit and I had

written a letter or two to the local paper just as sort of a general thing of support it wasn't anything radical or anything that even got me ostracized in the community at this point but this was at the time that the oral arguments were being made before the Supreme Court and there was a very sweet old gentleman he must have been in his 70s at that time named McElwain
He was the attorney for the school board who was resisting this suit by the NAACP and of course the local blacks.
And he was reporting to the Lions Club immediately after he came back from this oral, the oral arguments before the Supreme Court.
And it didn't occur to anybody in that Lions Club that there might be some support in the white community for the blacks in this case.
And I tried to be very discreet, and certainly I respected Mr. McElwain.
I didn't want to challenge him, but I asked some fairly sharp questions of him.
And that was the end of my relationship to the Lions Club in Prince Edward County.
He was, of course, he had been involved in this all the way through.
He had a brother who was a Presbyterian missionary in Japan, and I respected him and I respected the family.
But when the actual decision was made by the Supreme Court, there was complete shock and dismay in the county
And then, of course, is when my role in this, as limited and remote as it was, I had no real role at all except within the white community.
And this was a very negative role because my position was never accepted.
There were two issues in the church at that time.
One was the reunion of the two branches of the Presbyterian Church, which was defeated at that General Assembly, which came immediately after the cause, primarily, of this integration decision.
And then this question of the integration of the schools.
And I took my side, the liberal side of both.
I was commissioner to that General Assembly.
That was in Montreat, North Carolina?
Well, it often is and has been in Montreat.
It was in Atlanta at this particular time.
But at that General Assembly, I got a petition from about 90% of the elders of that Presbytery, West Hanover Presbytery, which was the region west of Richmond over to Lynchburg.
asking me two things.
There was a resolution concerning integration before General Assembly asking me to oppose integration at the General Assembly and asking me to oppose the reunion of the two churches.
Well, I couldn't do that in conscience.
are in the pulpit or anywhere else.
So I wrote a letter and mimeographed it and sent it to all of those elders who had signed this petition from all of the churches, including out of 12 out of 13 of my elders in the section.
And that's when it really hit the fan.
Because
What I was saying was that the gospel couldn't be preached by popular vote, and that I had to vote my conscience on this, as I believe my conscience was enlightened by Scripture.
Well, from that point, it was just a question of how long I could remain in the community.
It was a traumatic experience, because I loved those people.
good, solid people, but they were just living in a different age.
And it was just incomprehensible that black children could go to school with the white children in the little worship school, which was nearby, and all the children and the professors went there.
And it was just beyond, they couldn't accept it.
One of the
real stories here, and it was a personal story, and one of friendship, and I believe mutual respect.
There was an old doctor in the congregation.
He was pushing 80, but everybody there was old.
This was one of the problems.
The average age of my session was 70.
But this old doctor, Dr. Moore, he was the old family doctor for all of the people in the area.
But most of his practice was with blacks.
And he was a devoted person in terms of his Christian vocation and his desire to help people and so forth.
But he lived in another age.
He was a staunch segregationist.
And he was the one, this was such a traumatic thing for the people in the church, they couldn't even talk to me about it.
But old Dr. Moore was one who would talk to me.
And after a church service in which I may have made some reference, or in some cases devoted services to issues of this kind, everybody else would,
I wouldn't even speak to him, but he would argue with me, and many a time there had been Sunday dinners waiting two or three hours as we would have it out.
But, you see, the difficulty was with the position that I took, I couldn't really challenge
on moral grounds the argument of a man like Dr. Moore because he provided the only medical services available to most of the blacks in the south half of Prince Edward County.
Many a time I've seen that man, as old and firm as he was, come in at dawn

because he had to go right by our house as he went out to this rural area and he was serving the blacks either death or birth or an acute illness and he was the kind of doctor who would be there and see it through but with all of his service and all of his idea of using
his services, Christian vocation.
He was a segregationist.
This is the incongruity in the situation.
Of course, he was, this was paternalism in the traditional Southern fashion.
To be nice to them, do everything you can to help them and so forth, even help their school situation.
But still, everything was still in the control of the whites, and it was sort of a paternal looking out after their interests, and so forth.
And this was the whole community, but it was particularly Dr. Moore, and as I say, I admired and respected him.
I think there was a lot of mutual admiration and respect in that community, but the point came when it was no longer possible to carry on an effective ministry there.
And what little support, I did have some support from the students, but it was not an outspoken support.
It was sort of a private thing.
We're with you, Mr. Bill, or we're...
We agree with you, but we can't go home and say this.
And most of them were from rural or small towns in Virginia.
But at any rate, it hit close home a lot of other ways, too.
I have a pretty thick eye.
I mean, I can endure this kind of situation up to a point, though it hurt.
But Agnes doesn't.
And she had a very strong reaction to some of this.
And for her mental health and other reasons, we had to leave.
First it was to go on, and then I was wrapping up my doctoral work at that time.
So we resigned.
I simply went to Richmond, and we were there for, oh, for three more months.
that summer and then I was given a look out for something else.
That's how we became Texans, because it was not possible after that experience to go back to the Deep South.
But at any rate, this was more a personal thing.
Now, as far as the
the actual litigation is concerned, I had no part in that whatsoever.
I simply met on very few occasions with some of the people who had the same kind of concerns that I did.
and was able at least to demonstrate that there was some white support for the things that they were trying to achieve.
Thurgood Marshall came down, and is that where you met him?
Yes, yes, this is where I met him.
He was in New York also.
Yes, well, yes, that was his base, but he visited, I think,

All four or five, some of them didn't really get to this, but there were a number of challenges, legal challenges, that were made in the courts, both in the North and in the South, so that this could come before the Supreme Court as a fundamental legal issue that could be decided once and for all.
And he was the real architect of this whole structure.
I mean, his whole point was this one unconstitutional point, the separate but equal, which obviously, as it was practiced and carried out both in the North and the South, was both unequal.
Well, it was separate, but it was unequal.
There was no possible equality on the basis of a separate school system, I suppose.

There was real consternation in Prince Edward County, and I have an idea that what you've seen in the New York Times dealt primarily with the abolition of the public schools in Prince Edward County, which came after that.
Actually, it came, this was in the words, in fact, this is what they had been saying, threatening all along, that if this...
and of course it went through the appellate courts and up to the Supreme Court and was won all the way.
But if this was sustained by the Supreme Court, Prince Edward County had no choice but to abolish public schools.
And of course what that meant was, and it was very obvious to everyone who was involved here, there would be no schooling for the blacks.
The whites would organize their own private schools.
And the only way to get any kind of education at all for children was to enroll in these private schools.
So there was a great deal of scurrying about and organizing the private school system.
And then the year that I left, the county abolished the public school system.
And what that meant was that even
The limited schools that they had were not available anymore.
And for about five or six years, there was no public school in Prince Edward County at all.
Now, eventually, they were forced by court order to reopen the public schools.
But it was too late for a lot of the kids who grew up without any schooling whatsoever.
And then when the school resumed, it was, well, there was consternation.
It was chaos in the public schools that were reordering it.
And not really until now has it settled down.

Now, there's still a private school system, but I think most whites, particularly in academic communities like Hampton-Sydney and Longwood, out of principle, they send their children to public school, but with some supplementary schooling and so forth.
And maybe they use the private schools in part
There are a lot of difficult issues and questions here.
Of course, the fact that a large majority of people in Prince Edward County, particularly school age, are black is a factor here.
But I've often thought in subsequent years how that might have been handled in a better way.
Of course, there had to be confrontation.
in order for, had to be legal confrontation, in order for things to be done that were actually accomplished.
But in terms of the church and its role, I don't know.
I think I would have done things differently.
I think I would have been, I would have taken my stand.
I had to do that.
But I think I would have been
less abrasive about it, or at least abrasive in terms of the old paternal society in Prince Edward County.
I was an outsider, you see.
One of the funny things, I had a friend who was presiding at the congregational meeting when I was called,
And he swears up and down that the first 15 minutes of reporting on me, they were reporting on my wife's family.
Agnes' father was a graduate of Agnes.
and the family was very much a part of that Virginia tradition and so forth.
But I was this Arkansan interloper who was acceptable on the basis of my wife's family.
But no, there were real personal times and it was really an anguishing experience for all of us because we were close.
And I think there was a great deal of acceptance of what I was trying to get across as a pastor there.
Yet, there can be only partial acceptance.
And it was a source of great distress to a lot of people.
And I felt that I had to go and stay and find a job.
I think I would have, except for the kind of pressures that we had with children.
That kind of pressure she put on me was too much in that kind of situation.
She's the one who got the personal brunt of it, you see.
I can sort of live up on this plane and take my stand.
I can do no other, this kind of thing.
But on a personal level, it was very difficult.
Well, we came on.
to the campus ministry here at North Texas and at TWU and taught in both institutions.

And the same issue followed me right here because the first thing that happened here at North Texas was court integration of North Texas State University, the first institution in Texas, or at least public institution, that decreed integration.
Well, we were prepared for it.
And in those days, this was days of the large, many students were involved in student movements.
Quite a different situation in Sydney because students became involved right at the beginning.
Our Presbyterian group, which was really as much an ecumenical group as anything else, integrated rather massively from the start.
And the kids would picket the campus theater.
We would continue to be, at least for a while.
You see, the community was still segregated in Denton, but the North Texas was integrated.
Really, it was a very wise policy of Dr. Matthews, the president at that time.
He was trying to keep the publicity down to a minimum.
and yet to make everything internally, make the things work.
And so, there were a lot of interesting situations there.
For instance, one thing our group did was to integrate Austin College up here.
We had, our kids were going up there, it was some kind of weekend college rally.
And we had four black kids who signed up to go.
So I called up Ashby Johnson, who was a chaplain of Austin College at that time, a good friend, and said, we're going to integrate your college.
And he was completely sympathetic with us.
I mean, he said the time had come, and he was just hoping for an occasion where
things simply could go on and happen.
It was done, and no fuss and fanfare about it.
And as it turned out, there were some other things happening back here.
Only one black girl went with our group.
We had about eight or ten there.
It went smoothly, no problems, and
As far as Austin College was concerned, it had already happened, you see, because there were progressive people in charge of things then.
But it was rather interesting that it was our group that posed the issue.
And, of course, my warning Ashby Johnson in advance of what was happening helped him to prepare for it and to make sure that there were no incidents and this kind of thing.
But the black gal who went up there had a wonderful time, and it was a happy occasion for all, and so we were real pleased with that.
But North Texas really pioneered this situation in Texas as far as the public schools were concerned.
I give Dr. Matthews, who was president at that time, great credit for the way he handled it.
You see, when the blacks came in to North Texas, it was on a massive basis.
I think about 400.
Many of the graduate students came in at the same time.
One of the funny things that happened
along with his first integrated class, who were a number of football players, some basketball players.
And in this first group was little Abner Haynes, who was a terrific hatback, slickest running hatback I think I'd ever seen up to that point.
And as soon as he was in his first game as a freshman, integration was suddenly enthusiastic.
I think that really made it a lot easier, because Little Abner, and there were a couple of others, and then about three or four years later, Mean Joe Green came in.
And so that took care of it.
But you know, I was real interested.
It was also the time of Oscar Robertson in Cincinnati.
And Cincinnati and North Texas were in the same conference at that time.
And in the old gym, we went to a game, and Oscar Robertson and two or three other blacks were on the Cincinnati team.
And I think North Texas at that time had one or two black players, but they were not prominent players.
They were just on the team, I think, when I got in the game.
But when Oscar Robertson came to town, of course he was the drawing card for Blacks and Pikes Alive, I noticed that every black student at North Texas was at that game.
And I was wondering there whether they had come to cheer for Oscar Robertson because he was a celebrity, he was the great player.
And the thing that
that impressed me or convinced me that integration was really a success at North Texas is when those black students were cheering for North Texas.
I mean, they came to see Oscar Robertson.
They had great admiration and respect for that kind of a building, but they were cheering their own team.
They were a part of
the North Texas situation, even though very limited participation by black students and by black basketball players.
At that time, of course, things have completely changed since then.
It's mostly black now, everywhere, as far as basketball is concerned.
But those have been
some of the experiences, and North Texas was very much in the fan of integration.

When it first happened, I was reading in Time Magazine something about how there was no, there were no black students in white colleges in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, and no public ones in all of Texas.
And there were 400-odd in North Texas at that time.
But this is how much Dr. Matthews had been able to keep it quiet until it was a success, and then it was published.
But that was just sort of a funny sidelight that, of course, Time and New York Times and others were reporting on these things for several years after the Brown Supreme Court decision in 1954.
But it's come a long way.
Well, this, my whole career, if you could call it that, has been dominated by this issue.
Not by choice, necessarily.
I just happen to be in the places where it happened.
And having certain convictions and being all a little bit confrontational about
and so forth, I guess I've been involved more directly than some other ministers.
Most of them shared the convictions that I've had, they just haven't been quite as outspoken or vocal about it, or haven't been placed in the situations where they had to make decisions of this kind.
So when I was on the staff of the National Council of Churches,
The question was raised, and this was the higher education staff.
At that time, I was director of Faculty of Christian Fellowship, which was the Christian faculty group in the country, ecumenical groups, all the denominations.
And we were beginning to raise some questions.
There were a good many people who were concerned about this, with the progression of immigration,
and the opportunities for black students broadening into the predominantly white higher educational institutions.
The black institutions, all black institutions, traditional, primarily church-related institutions and state ones, were more and more getting into the backwaters.
They were being bypassed.
Most of them seemed to be with the most progressive blacks, so those with the best training in the public schools and so forth going on to integrated institutions.
It was more a matter of remedial training in some of these backwater black institutions.
So there were a number of conferences

involving all the boards and agencies of the predominantly white denominations that had sponsored these schools and also the black denominations that had had these at the very core of their being for many years because these black colleges were tremendously important to the blacks.
In fact, I would say the only two indigenous black institutions
for the church and the black college.

And as a result of these consultations, and this came out of the National Council of the Churches primarily, the decision was made that these indigenous institutions in the black community needed to be supported and brought up to date and brought into the

the academic view, and so forth, to a much more extent, which meant going to foundations, increasing church support, trying to sponsor government programs to particularly to support this type of institution to go out on all fronts and to try to strengthen these colleges, to integrate them, as was indicated by
still to maintain basically their control and the black control over these institutions.
Of course, in many cases, it was white nations in control.
But at any rate, to emphasize the fact that this is an indigenous black institution and that it has merit on its own.
It may not be able to attract the best black students in the future, but
there's still a role for him.
I think one thing that, I won't forget the name, he was president of Fisk College in Nashville, which was a very fine black institution.
But he was saying that what the, he was talking about Ivy League institutions and other
They said, what these institutions are looking for primarily is the top 5% in 100 million pound handbags.
And that was exactly true.
You see, the Ivy League was trying to skim off the cream of the crop.
Well, what do you do with all the rest of them?
I mean, they have to have educational opportunities, even if there has to be a lot of remedial work to bring them to the level of the college degree.
So I was assigned at that time by these consultations and this group.
It became a regular structure in the National Council of Churches to try to develop a program on all of these fronts that we were working on at that time to strengthen these colleges
The first thing I did was to visit everyone and talk to their presidents and their boards whenever possible, professors, and to make friendships and to see what might be done here.
And of course, it was a tremendously enlightening experience to me.
I had always thought of myself as being

very sympathetic to the blacks concerns and being a southerner myself I understood some of the mores hopefully from the black perspective as well as the white and so forth but I learned lots of new things one of the things at the beginning I would get this I would be trying to get some to understand something about how things were done or
what the power structure is in this particular school.
And some of these guys were telling me, say, Bill,
You don't understand the mores.
You can't think like a black or something like that.
Now, the particular issue in this case, I was trying to find out who really ran Paul Quinn College in Waco, Texas.
Now, it was traditionally the bishop who lived right next to the campus.
But in this case, the bishop was 85 years old and was .
I mean, he was just the figurehead.
Well, I knew the president of the college.
He wasn't even a minister, and you almost had to be a minister to be in a power situation.
I knew he wasn't the... And so I was trying to find just who was running that college.
I never did find out.
I think it was the bishop's secretary.
It was...
Well, they didn't call him a secretary.
He was a minister, and he was the bishop's administrator or something like that.
But I never did get to him.
That was the thing.
I couldn't really talk to him about these programs and so on.
But at any rate, they would say, Bill, you don't understand the nuances of this situation.
And the nuance was, who was boss?
I mean, who was really boss?
So I got into lots of situations like that, and I was accepted.
But I was working with them and trying to do things.

Well, what we finally did, and this was with the help of the Ford Foundation primarily, I found an administrator, a staff person at the Ford Foundation who was really interested in going ahead with this thing.

So he made a grant to our National Council office, really it was just a grant to take care of the structure and the meetings and my salary and things like this for a couple of years while we tried to develop something.
And then, one of the, of course we were working,
all of the people in political power in the black community at that time.
Now this was beginning Lyndon Johnson's administration.
Civil rights measures were being passed and this whole business of special grants for black institutions.
It was no, it was
equality, presumably, but it was, no, it wasn't equality, it was the affirmative action and over and above grants for those because of the minority background and so forth.
It's pretty well gone by the boards now, but there was a lot of idealism in those days, and special programs were set up specifically between black colleges from health education, welfare, and GW.
I spent a good bit of time in Washington trying to work through some of these things with black presidents.
Benny Mays, who was the head of Morehouse College, I think he was already retired, but he was, I guess, the most respected black figure in education at that time.
He was helpful, and this president of Fisk, and oh, a number of others.
There were some great men involved.
in that area, but I was a sort of an operator working in and out using the influence of black educators and making proposals and so forth.
And one of the things we did was to try to set up the consortium idea among the black colleges, that is to allow
regional areas of the black colleges.
Because a lot of these programs, academic programs we were proposing, no one college was big enough or strong enough really to do it, even with the influx of a lot of money.
They were too small and too weak to do that.
But we figured that on the basis of a consortium, we could go pretty far.
in, say, putting one good business program in a consortium of several colleges.
